qas.question: What positive visual component can knots sometimes add to decorative pieces?
What term is used to describe what knots can do to affect the finish of things made from wood even when they've been painted?
Is bleed easy or difficult to control?
The stain from a knot bleeding is usually brownish or what other color?
In what stage of processing does knot primer need to be applied for maximum effectiveness?

context: In some decorative applications, wood with knots may be desirable to add visual <a0_0>interest<a0_0/>. In applications where wood is painted, such as skirting boards, fascia boards, door frames and furniture, resins present in the timber may continue to '<a1_0>bleed<a1_0/>' through to the surface of a knot for months or even years after manufacture and show as a <a3_0>yellow<a3_0/> or brownish stain. A knot primer paint or solution, correctly applied during <a4_0>preparation<a4_0/>, may do much to reduce this problem but it is <a2_0>difficult<a2_0/> to control completely, especially when using mass-produced kiln-dried timber stocks.
